Review.author: Brian W
Review.title: Expensive for a disposable camera, avoid it

Text.text: Can't give it a zero, so 1 star it is.
This was a Christmas present for our daughter in 2015 and she really like the color and everything else about it.
It worked ok and the zink printing is really neat.
She and her friends had a blast printing little selfies and pictures of themselves for projects, ornaments, and who knows what else.
She almost made it through the initial 30 pack of paper in an almost 12 month period.
So maybe around 24 prints later, ironically a few days before Christmas 2016, the camera died.
It wouldn't charge or turn on, and couldn't be seen when plugged into any computer, nothing at all dead.....
I contacted customer service via email and the person who responded was helpful, asked about things I had tried, and suggested I try some things.
Although some of the suggested things were things I'd already told them I'd done, I tried them again to no avail.
Swapping cables, plugs, or computers had any effect.
The reset button did nothing and the suggested firmware update couldn't be attempted since no computer would see the camera.
So still a dead camera.
The consensus was that the non-replaceable battery had failed.
The rep eventually asked me to provide a copy of the invoice for the camera which I did.
I was then informed that there was nothing they could do for me since it was now over 12 months since the order date of the camera.
Not the delivered date or the actual day it was received since it was a Christmas gift, but the day I placed the order on Amazon which was several days before it actually got delivered.
So it seems that they're aware of the battery issues and aren't willing to stand behind the product.
Camera comes with no userguide...

I have tried several times to contact GadgetBasket but no one has gotten in touch with me.
It would be really nice if someone could please help me out since one of the cameras is very defective.

I am in love with this Polaroid snap camera!
I love the nostalgia of it!
I like that you can choose to print it with the standard Polaroid frame or without.
I also like the sepia or black and white options to take your photos as well as the standard color option.
There's also a 10 second timer, if needed.
It has an internal battery and comes with a usb cord for charging purposes.
I think this is the perfect companion for a smash book (which is what I've been using it for) with the sticky back on the zink photo paper.
There is a slot for a microSD card (not included).
I love that this option is available so that I can also have a digital version of my photo.
I have not yet uploaded the images I've taken to check the digital quality.
In the times before smartphones, Polaroids were the best way to instantly share photos or to keep a tangible memory of a specific moment.
The Polaroid Snap brings me back to that time and I love it.
Best feature that it has is the ability to save your picture to a micro SD memory card where you can print additional Polaroids and distribute.

Review.author: Atsuna M.
Review.title: Reminds me of the lomo toy cameras!

Text.text: The build of this camera is soo nice!
The cap is a magnet that just snaps onto the camera lens and the flash button acts as the power button.
When you want to turn the camera off, the flash is flipped down and when you want to turn the camera on, you slick on the flash button and it'll flip open.
There's 3 color settings: black and white, sepia, and color.
The quality of the photos definitely reminds me of the lomo toy cameras that were popular in the early 2000's.
The photos have a vintage, nostalgic tone, so don't expect an HD or super clear images.
I think it's still a fun camera to have to capture candid moments with the instant gratification of instaprint photos.
Just set your expectation low in terms of the quality of the images because I think it's trying to mimic film photos.

Review.author: C. Berman
Review.title: I absolutely love that it does not require ink

Text.text: I purchased this camera for my niece who loves hanging photos in her room and showing her teachers/friends pictures but can't always take her phone with digital photos where she goes.
I absolutely love that it does not require ink.
Like older Polaroid cameras, the ink is basically in the paper.
She has enjoyed this camera so far!
It is very easy to use.
In fact a simple photographic representation of instructions is all that is needed.
The look is retro, with the 'old school' Polaroid rainbow.
That look is making a come back so she really thought it was 'cool'.
It comes with a wrist strap so when she is out and about she can make sure she doesn't misplace the camera.
And it charges by USB!
No batteries to replace!!!!
(That is my favorite part).
I even purchased extra photo paper for her because it's so inexpensive and she can have fun making copies of any photos she likes.
I love that she doesn't have to make copies of every picture.
Just her favorites.
That is what sold me on this camera.
It's the best decision I've made for her Birthday!

Lets say you take a pic with two of your friends and everyone wants a pic, the camera only outputs one single polaroid image, theres no way to command the camera to print a second or 3rd copy...bummer.
You may recall that classic polaroid images had an extra wide margin at the bottom to write details about pic.
This camera does the same but instead of being at the bottom it runs along the side of the print, it just looks odd.
I wished there was an option to have an even white border all around the print but there isn't.
On the surface it's a fun little camera but I think it needs to undergo one more revision before achieving greatness.

This is a design flaw as there is no lock or latch to keep it from popping open at an inconvenient moment like in your purse... To add frustration, the shutter button is extremely easy to press to snap a pic.
That combination is deadly for a device that needs the printer side to be unobstructed in order to not damage the camera.
If you buy this, budget for the case as well.

This camera, however, produces VERY poor quality images, no matter what the ambient light level and no mattter what settings are used.
The printed pictures are either way to bright or are unfocused.
But the thing that makes this purchase a true waste of money is that the pop-up view finder does not represent the image that is captured by the camera.
Centering a personâ€™s head and shoulders in the viewfinder, for example, results in a photo of that personâ€™s torso and upper legs.

As a result, the user is forced to play a guessing game and â€œoffsetâ€ the image in the viewfinder in a blind attempt to capture the desired image (ie aim above the personâ€™s head in an attempt to get an actual picture of their face).

Review.author: CG
Review.title: ... Polaroid fan and user from way back and am delighted the company has stayed in the game

Text.text: I am a Polaroid fan and user from way back and am delighted the company has stayed in the game.
This context led to the SNAP being given to me as a Valentine's Day gift.
I've had a blast this camera!
People LOVE it!
I think I sold a few last night at a party.

Here's the thing: I have several cameras including 2 DSLRS, point and shoot Powershot, GoPro, which I share because when I pick up the SNAP I have a different mindset than when I'm in photographer mode with the other cameras.
I am creating mementos to give away in the moment.
The viewfinder isn't always easy for me, so sometimes the photo is framed differently than planned.
There is a brief lag for the flash, so I entertain until shot is captured (a few more seconds than usual with other cameras).
I am old school, so I like saying, 'Here's a shot for your refrigerator.'
People get a kick out of it.
Last night at a retirement party, responses ranged from, 'Oh my god, I didn't know they still made Polaroids,' to one man who just kept laughing and laughing as he looked at the pic.
Fun surprise when you can hand someone the photo booth (4 tiny pics on one sheet) version.
Choosing black and white or color options, it's all good.
With a white border or edge to edge - you choose.
One time as the photo exited the camera, it fell into my beer - I can report the photo held up fine and everyone at the table got a good laugh.
I highly recommend this product if you use it the way it is intended and have realistic expectations.
The magnetic lens cap cover adds to the cool factor, and it's another fun feature to show off.
Based on the reactions I receive when I hand over the pics to people, the film sheets are worth every penny.
Last night I got 20-some shots on one charge.
People think it's magic: no batteries, no ink, dry immediately.
Sometimes, I 'shake it like a Polaroid picture,' just for fun.

It is very difficult to use, taking me online only for the firmware update (which I am not even certain worked) and the User Guide (which could easily print to one page but for some reason is 12 pages long, and still does not include the reason for the flashing lights).
It's just plain irritating to get this set up.
It doesn't come with either the paper or the SD card, so plan to invest another $30 or more.

It could be that I am not technical enough but...it shouldn't matter...here I am with a $130 investment into something that, as far as I can tell, doesn't work, and doesn't give me any indication on how to fix it.

Review.title: This is a fantastic little instant camera

Text.text: This is a fantastic little instant camera.
For those reviewers complaining about the colors, it sounds like they aren't familiar with the type of photography this kind of camera is simulating.
No, the pictures are not super-sharp, high-definition prints, but that's not what this camera is trying to be.
Under the 'standard' color setting, the photos come out looking like a film camera from the late 80s, where the 'sepia' photos look like they were taken from my grandpa's camera from the 60s.
The focus has been sharp and impressive at all distances I've shot.
I'm very pleased with this camera

The Polaroid Snap is a fun, retro, instant print camera with nostalgia and novelty value.

You cannot use it as an instant print camera without Snap compatible ZINK Photo Paper, and it does not come with so much as a single piece of ZINK (zero ink) paper, so you should order some when you order a Snap.For someone who is in the market for a fun, retro, instant print camera with nostalgia and novelty value that they can take to parties, etc., the Snap is cool enough that despite the fact that you have to buy a pack of ZINK pape in order to use it as it's meant to be used, I can easily rate it 5 stars.
But keep in mind that I'm a grandpa who has still has photo albums filled with Polaroids that I took in the sixties.
And when I look at what comes out of the Snap, I definitely get the nostalgia effect, especially when I select the print option that puts an old-fashioned Polaroid border around the print.
The print quality itself adds to the nostalgia, in that the print quality is apparently designed and intended to be reminiscent of original Polaroid prints.
The Snap has no built-in memory, but it does have a slot for a microSD card.

Technically, if you put a microSD card in a Snap, you can use the Snap without ZINK paper, and you can access the images by putting the microSD card into another device or by connecting the Snap to a computer with the included USB cable (which is also the charging cable).
But based on my experience, I'd say there'd be no point in using a microSD card in the Snap unless you are also using ZINK paper.
Let's say that you're at a party and you take a Snap shot of someone and give them the instant print.
Great camera!

This camera comes with a 20 sheet set with 2x3 inch Zink paper.
The paper comes in two sleeves of 10 within foil wrapping so not to be easily exposed by the Sun.

When putting the paper in, the camera didn't come with a set of instructions within the box, although it did give a website to be able to download the latest firmware, but I wanted to see if I could figure it out on my own and through trial and error, I figured that the paper goes picture side up.
So you can see the backing of the paper has the logo and writing on it that will face the inside of the camera.
I showed in the video exactly how to do this.
You don't have to slide it through or anything, you just place it flat in there and close it quickly so there isn't much light exposure.

Review.author: jlam949
Review.title: this Polaroid Snap camera works pretty well. Itâ€™s the size of the typical digital ...

Text.text: Compared to the Fujifilm Instax MINI 8, this Polaroid Snap camera works pretty well.
Itâ€™s the size of the typical digital camera.
So you can slip it into your back pocket unlike the Instax.
But I do admit, the Instax is cuter, looks more like a traditional camera with better color options.
But I guess it comes down to more of a preference.
The Snap uses zinc paper, so when the photo prints, it looks like you printed directly from a printer rather than an old school Polaroid photo, like the Instax (prints slower too.)
The photos are smaller than the Instax but the Zinc paper has a sticker backing, so itâ€™s like a sticker pix.
The Snap photos can be printed with a white border and can be printed in color, sepia and black in white.
But what I do like is that this camera can print with a photo booth option, so 4 photos in one print.
And this camera has a Micro SD Card option, which is a plus for me.
I normally end up giving the printouts to others, but now I have a copy for myself.
The only difference that Iâ€™ve notice is that the SNAP is on auto, while the Instax has lighting options.
And the Instax is at a lower price point.
Other than that, they work pretty similar.
You still need good lighting and your photos should probably be within 3-5 feet away.

Review.title: The pictures were not very good. I liked the idea of having an internal ...

Text.text: The pictures were not very good.
I liked the idea of having an internal memory for maybe saving the photos later, but it kind of took away from the idea behind polaroid.
Polaroid, an iconic brand makes another iconic product, the Polaroid Snap.
The new Polaroid Snap comes in a sleek and stylish design that is trimmer and lighter than it's predecessors.
Delivering excellent quality instant images, there were a few changes that I loved.
I am able to select a color scheme from button on the top of the camera that will expose the film in those range of colors, creating a unique artistic feel.
Also, an accidental discover, the images are all stickers!
Go ahead and take a shot, peel off the back, and have an instant brand new bumper sticker or another souvenir for the refrigerator.
Polaroid truly tries to innovate, and the Polaroid Snap is a testament to that.
Took this Polaroid out for the first time to Havasupai and it was awesome!
Super easy to carry around on our hikes.
The colors of the photos came out great.
It is a really fun camera for instant photos!
As a photographer, the absolute coolest thing about this camera is its ability to capture 'moments' in a classic, hazy way reminiscent of the original instant print Polaroid cameras.
Simply amazing, not to mention the cameras themselves are absolutely gorgeous.
100%, would recommend.
The Polaroid Snap is so fun to use and also makes a GREAT gift for anyone.
It's cool, fun, user friendly and I absolutely love it.
My niece also got one for Christmas and was still loving and using it during the fourth of July.
I love the different colors and the fact that the photos print instantaneously!

This would seriously be the perfect gift for someone, including for my grandmother, who thinks that all pictures are going to be 'lost in the cloud' one day and likes to print them, but doesn't like to go to the store.
It would also be nostalgic for people who use to use polaroid cameras.
I love that Polaroid snap brings back the hard copy photo with just the touch of a button.

Review.author: Amazon Customer
Review.title: Great camera if you like constantly clearing photo paper jams

Text.text: Great camera if you like constantly clearing photo paper jams.
We purchased this camera for our daughter for Christmas.
She was thrilled when she opened it.
However, a few things just on the initial unboxing of the product.
There are absolutely no instructions.
It took us a little while to even figure out how to turn the camera on.
You have to press down on the view finder to turn the camera on and off.
Once we figured that out, we were excited to take some pictures.
But again, there were no instructions with the camera that told you how to load the photo paper in to the camera.
Once we figured that out, we tried to take some pictures.
We used the photo paper that came with the camera and loaded 10 sheets of photo paper into the camera.
First attempt, jam.
After clearing the paper out of the camera, tried again.
The blue zinc reader card came out after taking the first picture.
So, we tried again.
Next attempt was another jam.
I removed all of the photo paper from the camera and put 5 sheets in to the camera.
It didn't seem to matter that there were fewer sheets of photo paper loaded.
The camera jammed probably 70-80% of the time.
We finally resorted to loading a single sheet at a time.
It still jams even with just a single piece of photo paper.
My daughter still likes playing with the camera but this camera is not worth the price tag.
We can store photos on the camera with a micro sd card, which is a nice feature.
If we really want to print photos, it would be a lot less frustrating to send the digital prints to Snapfish or other service to get that done.
It's frustrating fighting with the photo paper and clearing jams 70-80% of the time.

This is a great idea, but pretty poor execution.
Lets start with the packaging.
There are pretty much NO instructions.
Admittedly, there isn't a lot to figure out, BUT there are things you would never know without accidentally doing it and thus wasting some of the expensive zinc paper.

For example if you hold the shutter button down longer than intended the camera with take a 4 in 1 quad photo, which is actually pretty cool, but how would you know that until you did it and wasted at least one zinc sheet?

Also there are error codes represented by lights on the back, however they are ANOTHER thing that they do not explain, so you can guess what they mean, but even after searching polaroid.com and messages boards I have found no answer for my issues.
Another major problem is the viewfinder, which is tiny and does not accurately depict what ends up on the final printed image.
Also, it acts as the only power button in popup form, and if you carry the camera in anything, such as a backpack or pocket, it turns on and drains the battery before you can use it.
The idea of this thing is fantastic, however its execution, lack of directions, and frequent errors are very hard to recommend the current generation of this product.

I don't think this retro fad will last, but you never know.

The Polaroid Snap is a fun, retro, instant print camera with nostalgia and novelty value.

You cannot use it as an instant print camera without Snap compatible ZINK Photo Paper, and it does not come with so much as a single piece of ZINK (zero ink) paper, so you should order some when you order a Snap.

For someone who is in the market for a fun, retro, instant print camera with nostalgia and novelty value that they can take to parties, etc., the Snap is cool enough that despite the fact that you have to buy a pack of ZINK pape in order to use it as it's meant to be used, I can easily rate it 5 stars.
But keep in mind that I'm a grandpa who has still has photo albums filled with Polaroids that I took in the sixties.
And when I look at what comes out of the Snap, I definitely get the nostalgia effect, especially when I select the print option that puts an old-fashioned Polaroid border around the print.

The print quality itself adds to the nostalgia, in that the print quality is apparently designed and intended to be reminiscent of original Polaroid prints.The Snap has no built-in memory, but it does have a slot for a microSD card.

Technically, if you put a microSD card in a Snap, you can use the Snap without ZINK paper, and you can access the images by putting the microSD card into another device or by connecting the Snap to a computer with the included USB cable (which is also the charging cable).
But based on my experience, I'd say there'd be no point in using a microSD card in the Snap unless you are also using ZINK paper.
Let's say that you're at a party and you take a Snap shot of someone and give them the instant print.
